text:
- [Jim] Hello and welcome
to the AWS Builder Guides.

My name is Jim Loveland. I'm
a Solutions Architect at AWS.

In this tutorial, we'll learn
about AWS Cost Categories,

a tool that allows you
to group your AWS costs

in ways that align with
your business needs.

After a brief introduction to
the tool and its use cases,

I'll show you how to use
it in the AWS console.

In AWS, the basic category
for accounting and billing
is the account.
AWS organizations

allows you to centralize
billing for multiple accounts
into a single payer account.

AWS Cost Categories allows
you even more freedom

in how you group your cost
and usage information,
by projects, say, or by team.
It allows you to allocate shared costs
to entities in your enterprise
according to rules that you define.

And the groups and rules you
define in Cost Categories

can be propagated to other AWS
financial management tools,
as we will see in the demo.
For purposes of the demo,

I created this fictitious
organization chart
for any company incorporated

in order to illustrate
three common use cases
for Cost Categories.
The first question we might ask
if we're an executive of any company is,
how do I allocate cost by team?

The costs are reported
by account by default,
but we have two accounts per team.
The second question we might ask
is how we can allocate cost by project.

In this example, we
have two different teams

spinning up resources to work
on project A and project B.

How do I account for the
total cost of project A?
The third question we might ask
is how we allocate a shared cost.
In other words,

a cost that is paid for
by a central account
but which needs to be charged back
to business units, teams or accounts
that actually consume the service.

Examples might be support
charges, networking services,
or reserved instance savings

that are actually initially
attributed to a payer account.
Now I'll enter my AWS console

and show you how to answer
all three of these questions
using AWS Cost Category.
I'm in the home screen of my AWS account.
Cost Categories is a feature

in the Billing and Cost
Management Services,
so I will navigate there.

And then click on Cost
Categories in the left hand menu.
In the interest of time,

I'm simply going to walk you
through the Cost Categories

that I created previously,
beginning with Team.

When you first create a Cost
Category, you choose a name,

and then you make a choice
of the lookback period.
You can either apply this Cost Category
from this month forward in time,
or you can apply it retroactively
for the previous 12 months.

So here I've defined two
team cost categories.

Team A is going to consist
of these two accounts,
and team B consists of these two accounts.
Once I've defined that, I click next.
If you were doing this for the first time,

you would have a chance to
create the cost category
as opposed to saving the changes.

The second cost category
we're going to review
is that of Project.
Here we're going to define project A

as consisting of everything
that has a cost allocation tag

with the key value pair of
project name equal to project A.
Project B is defined as everything,

all resources that have
the cost allocation tag

with the key value pair of
project name equal to project B.
Click next.

Now I'm going to show you
how to allocate shared costs.
But before I do so,

I want to step back to
our organization chart
and show you what I wanna do.

We've already created cost
categories for Project and Team.
Behind the scenes,

I've gone ahead and created
three more cost categories
at the next highest level of aggregation.
Business unit one, business unit two,

and a shared services
business unit cost category.
So as a next step,

we're going to take the
shared services costs

and allocate them to the
other two business units

which represent any
company's cost centers.
So here I am back in the console,

and I'm gonna edit and
show you what I've done
with the shared costs category.
So I've gone and defined cost center one
as consisting of business unit one,

cost center two consisting
of business unit two,
and then the shared cost to split

consisting of the shared
services business unit.
I'm gonna hit next.
And unlike in the previous examples,
I click the button to add a split charge.
And what we get now is this screen here
that gives us the option to choose
which cost do we want to split.
And in our cases I chose the shared costs.
And where do you want to allocate them?
That's the target value.

I chose cost center one
and cost center two.

And here we get to choose the
formula we're going to use
to allocate those costs.

I chose to allocate them
in a fixed proportion

with 50% going to each
of the two cost centers.
Now I want to show you
how we can visualize our cost categories
in the other cost management tools in AWS.
We're gonna go to my Team cost category
and click view in AWS Cost Explorer.
In my Cost Explorer,

I'm gonna change my time
horizon to month to date
since that's where we began collecting
cost category information.
And what you can see here
is the Cost Explorer is presenting to me

my costs broken down as those
allocated to team A in green,
team B in blue,

and those costs that cannot
be allocated to any team
based on my formula in red.

This concludes this edition
of the AWS Builder Guides.
